contentrichtext.text: '''J. R. Hartley''' is the name of a fictional character in a popular advertisement promoting the yellow pages which was first shown in 1983.<ref name="GuardianObit">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2001/nov/30/advertising.broadcasting|title=Veteran singer-actor who found fame in TV ad dies, 95 | Media | The Guardian|work=Guardian|accessdate=13 March 2013}}</ref> The advertisement shows an elderly man (actor [[Norman Lumsden]]) asking in several [[second-hand]] [[bookshop]]s for "''Fly Fishing'' by J. R. Hartley". Every attempt fails, and the next scene shows him at home looking dejected. His daughter, sympathising, hands him the Yellow Pages; in the next scene he looks delighted as his end of a telephone conversation reveals that a shop has a copy of the book. He asks them to keep it for him. He responds at dictation speed to a question: 'My name? Oh, yes, it's J. R. Hartley.' The advertisement ends by promoting the Yellow Pages, the [[voiceover]] provided by actor [[Joss Ackland]]. In Britain's 2000 "Greatest TV Ads" poll, the advertisement was voted in the top 15.<ref name=Owen>{{cite book |author=Owen, James |title=Trout |publisher=Reaktion Books Ltd |location=London |year=2012 |isbn=9781861898777 |page=125 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=VHtZtD3RrdsC&pg=PA125&dq=J+R+Hartley&hl=en&sa=X&ei=eVZAUeDRHsXE4AOZkIHYAg&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=J%20R%20Hartley&f=false}}</ref><ref name="Channel 4 | 100 Greatest TV Ads">{{cite web | url=http://www.channel4.com/entertainment/tv/microsites/G/greatest/tv_ads/results.html | title=Channel 4 - 100 Greatest TV Ads | year=2000}} - 13th position</ref> When Lumsden died on 28 November 2001 at the age of 95, the advertisement was broadcast again in his memory, nearly 20 years after its first appearance. In February 2011, Yellow Pages re-made the advert, with fictional DJ Day V. Lately searching for a copy of his [[Trance (music)|trance]] remix ''Pulse and Thunder'',<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1354209/Day-V-Lately-Yellow-Pages-replace-JR-Hartley-trendy-DJ-new-TV-advert.html#axzz2KgYl7PFp ''Daily Mail'': Day V Lately? That name rings a bell: Yellow Pages updates charming old JR Hartley with a trendy DJ in new TV advert 13 February 2011]</ref> which was released for sale at the same time.<ref>[http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/entertainment/tv-radio/spoof-dance-track-by-dj-day-1096096 ''Daily Record'': Spoof dance track by DJ Day V Lately rockets up charts thanks to TV ad]</ref> The advertisement inspired author Michael Russell to publish ''Fly Fishing, Memories of Angling Days, by J. R. Hartley'' in 1991,.<ref>{{cite book |last=Hartley |first=J.R. |coauthor=Russell, Michael |title=Fly Fishing, Memories of Angling Days, by J.R. Hartley |publisher=Stanley Paul |location=London |isbn=9780091751920}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author=O'Reilly, Terry |coauthor=Tennant, Mike |year=2009 |title=The Age of Persuasion-How Marketing Ate our Culture |page=344 |publisher=Random House |location= |isbn=9781582435800 }}</ref> The book was a best seller and led to two additional best sellers under the pseudonym J. R. Hartley: ''J.R. Hartley Casts Again-More Memories of Angling Days'' (1992) and ''Golfing by J.
